column2: Information that protects 'personal information' or PII. Distinction depends on how easily data can be associated with a specific person.
Someone who can be ascertained with certainty (e.g., via SSN).
Someone who can be indirectly identified through a combination of factors (e.g., City + Gender + Birth Year).
The amount of effort required to link data to a specific individual.
Historically non-personal, but the FTC increasingly views static IP addresses as identifiable PI.
Data that is identifying without additional context (e.g., SSN, Passport #).
General data belonging to multiple people, needed in combination for identification (e.g., Height, Home Address).
Data combined with external knowledge to link it to an individual.
Removing identifying information or values from a data set.
Reducing granularity by replacing specific info with more general elements (e.g., removing house # from address).
Grouping the extreme ends of a range into a single category (e.g., income > $100k or < $20k) to hide outliers.
Replacing actual values with data from the same class to maintain statistical properties while hiding individuals.
Using statistics from groups of records rather than individual data.
A mathematical framework introducing 'noise' to provide a guarantee of indistinguishability for individuals in a dataset.
Methods to measure success of anonymization: k-anonymity, l-diversity, and t-closeness.
The primary focus of privacy protection laws (as opposed to Public Records).
Information like court filings that is generally less protected.
